p: Phytochemical analyses of G. gardneriana detected several classes of compounds, such as steroids, triterpenes, biflavonoids, and xanthones [ 61]. Several biflavonoids found and identified as volkensiflavone ( 23), 13-naringenin-II 8-eriodictyol (GB-2a; 24), fukugetin (or morelloflavone; 9), and fukugesid ( 18) have demonstrated analgesic effects [ 62]. A new biflavonoid isolated from G. gardneriana leaves, named GB2a-OMe ( 25), also presented a significant analgesic effect in the formalin test in mice in the neurogenic and inflammatory phases [ 63].
